In the final part of this 3 part series, Matthew Walker, professor of neuroscience at UC Berkeley and expert on sleep, discusses the omnipresent effects of insufficient sleep on everything from metabolism, appetite, athletic performance, decision-making, productivity, leadership, mental health, genetics, memory, and more. We also discuss the impact of caffeine and alcohol on sleep quality, the efficacy of sleep aids such as THC and CBD, and much more.

	Episode Details



	
	

		In the final part of this 3 part series, Matthew Walker, professor of neuroscience at UC Berkeley and expert on sleep, discusses the omnipresent effects of insufficient sleep on everything from metabolism, appetite, athletic performance, decision-making, productivity, leadership, mental health, genetics, memory, and more. We also discuss the impact of caffeine and alcohol on sleep quality, the efficacy of sleep aids such as THC and CBD, and much more. We discuss:  Sleep and insulin resistance [6:15]; Epigenetic changes with insufficient sleep, and the reversibility of lost sleep [18:00]; Sleep’s impact on exercise performance, appetite, and food choices [28:15]; Decision making, workplace production, leadership qualities, physical attractiveness, and more [43:15]; The broken water pipe analogy [49:30]; The negative effect of caffeine, alcohol, and high carb meals on sleep quality [53:30]; The efficacy of THC and CBD as sleep aids [1:05:30]; Sleep and mental health: A two-way street [1:16:45]; How sleep impacts memory, and Matthew’s current and upcoming projects [1:24:00]; Sleep’s impact on athletes: Looking at Formula One drivers [1:32:45] Translating the science to clinical application [1:57:00]; and More.  Learn more at www.PeterAttiaMD.com Connect with Peter on Facebook | Twitter | Instagram.

            Show NotesSleep and insulin resistance [6:15]
Paper: U of Chicago

Group of subjects measured by euglycemic clamps (keep glucose level steady by titrating insulin levels measure how well you dispose of glucose, primarily in muscle)
Got 4 hrs of sleep a night for 2 weeks (study now replicated with 4, 5, 6 hrs for one week)
50% reduction in ability to put glucose into their muscle – (Peter says: 1 of 5 most important physiologic functions)
Normal blood glucose is ~100 mg/dL (that is about 5 g of glucose/5 mmol/1 teaspoon of sugar in the blood)
Diabetic person has 200 mg/dL (10-11 mmol/2 teaspoons)
After one week of sleep deprivation, these previously healthy people are now looking pre-diabetic (“You’re writing them a Metformin prescription.”)

In other words…

Bloodstream levels of glucose are trivial compared to the amount in the muscles and liver
And if the body can’t clear that glucose, it affects everything
Peter, reflecting on his own metabolic dysfunction following med school, says poor sleep likely played a big role in his weight gain, insulin resistance, hypogonadism, low testosterone, etc.

What is the mechanism of how lack of sleep makes everything go awry?
Two major parts in the regulation of glucose:

First, beta cells (β cells) in pancreas sense spike in blood glucose and then release insulin
Secondly, to absorb blood glucose, tissues must be sensitive to insulin

Either, or both, can be affected

There can be a deficit in one of those two pathways (for example, in pregnancy, cells can become less sensitive so pancreas releases more insulin)
With sleep deprivation, you have a deficit in BOTH
β cells become insensitive to spike in blood glucose
And the cells become insensitive to signal of insulin
Now you have an inability to clear glucose on both sides of glucose equation

Why are the cells so mute to the signal of insulin?
⇒ Study showing impaired insulin signaling

Biopsied cells around umbilicus from healthy adults after 4-5 hours of sleep vs. 8 hrs of sleep
Looked at adipocyte cells taking up insulin
A critical process for getting glucose uptake is that Akt gets phosphorylated, which helps the GLUT4 transporter to go to surface of the cell, which then allows the cell to bring glucose in
Amount of insulin required to phosphorylate Akt almost doubled when subjects did not get enough sleep
This seems counterintuitive to Peter: “You’d think that the adipocyte would be even more sensitive to insulin as the body works harder to undergo esterification and put fat away given that the muscle becomes more resistant to insulin. Of course, this speaks to why many hormones are necessary to drive the metabolic derangement, because also the cortisol level would maybe even oppose that. In isolation, what you just described would actually oppose re esterification of fatty acid.” 
Matthew: “Yeah, but in my mind, I think what’s striking though it starts to tell you that individual cell types need sleep.”

What is the communication vehicle telling the phosphorylation to be less efficient?

We don’t know the intracellular mechanisms making this happen
But extracellular signals are clearly making intracellular functions maladaptive or less efficient

Epigenetic changes with insufficient sleep, and the reversibility of lost sleep [18:00]
“We often think of the impact of a lack of sleep on things like behavior, like driving, or making food choices. . . but there is something about a lack of sleep that will get even into cells themselves and alter intracellular functioning. If a single factor (sleep) can have its impact all the way from complex cognitive issues like decision making, all the way down to something like intracellular function, my goodness you need to look out if you’re depriving yourself of that one function.”
Epigenetic changes
PNAS paper

Group of healthy adults limited to 6 hours of sleep a day for 1 week (About the typical sleep adults get on avg.)
They found a change in the activity of 711 genes compared to when the subjects got 8 hrs of sleep (epigenetic change in 3% of their genome, only about 20,000 genes in our genome)
About half of the genes were upregulated and half downregulated
Downregulated (impaired) genes were ones associated with the immune system
The ones upregulated genes were associated with tumor production, long-term chronic inflammation, and stress / cardiovascular disease

⇒ Losing sleep is like doing a genetic test on yourself

People feel uncomfortable about genetically modified embryos, CRISPR, GMO, genetically modified foods, etc.
But you’re performing a similar experiment on yourself by not getting enough sleep
And if you don’t let your children get the sleep that they need, you may be inflicting inadvertently a genetic manipulation on them as well

Are sleep deprivation effects reversible with adequate sleep?

Sleep is not like a debt that you can repay (can’t make it up later, e.g., on weekends)
The damage from lack of sleep doesn’t seem to be reversible
However, that doesn’t mean that from this point forward, it’s a waste of time to start sleeping better

Evidence that fixing sleep (even in later life is a great thing): Sleep apnea study in older adults

Adults with sleep apnea were given a CPAP to ensure they got enough oxygen
Roughly half of the group complied with treatment and the other half did not
The ones who complied held off Alzheimer’s disease by 10 years
So correcting your sleep can actually change your risk of dementia
It’s a hopeful message: it’s never too late to start sleeping better

It’s hard to know what sleep was the direct cause of the slowing of cognitive decline
It could be that sleep is the influencing factor ⇒ because you’re sleeping, that you start to eat better, exercise more and better, have more energy to make healthier choices, etc.

Sleep’s impact on exercise performance, appetite, and food choices [28:15]
Physical activity and food choices

When you are underslept, you are less likely to be motivated to be physically active
And when you do convince yourself to exercise, 

Less force pressure you can generate
A reduction in the time it takes you to reach physical exhaustion up to 30% (E.g. if you normally reach physical exhaustion at 10k then you’ll reach it at 7k)


With enough sleep…

you will make better food choices
lower your caloric intake
increase calories expended
more motivated to be active
and work out more intensely


All of these things benefit cognitive decline, so if sleep is not ultimately the thing that is transacting the cognitive benefits, maybe is it the root cause 
That said, it may be playing some direct part, though, given what we’ve found about sleep and protein pathology in Alzheimer’s

It’s never too late to start sleeping better

If you have been sleep deprived in the past, don’t think that your fate is sealed
Just like people with T2D can improve by making changes to diet and exercise
And how long-time smokers can improve just by quitting (also parallels because people who quit smoking may then be motivated do make other positive health changes)

No hope for a randomized, prospective trial

Unethical to majorly deprive people of sleep
Also can even ethically deprive people with sleep apnea of CPAP

So how can we show benefits of correcting sleep?

Only way we’re going to be able to show the importance of sleep in kids is by having them sleep more
Kids of all ages sleep about 2 hours less per night than they did 50 years ago (no ethics committee would approve a study that would make kids lose 2 hours of sleep for a month yet we did it as a society)
Future studies will probably not be of sleep restriction but of sleep interventions and extensions

Diabetes and sleep apnea

People with untreated sleep apnea have far higher rates of diabetes
When they are treated, their diabetic profile improves markedly
But so do their food choices, their exercise, etc. so unclear if it’s a direct benefit of sleep improving cellular processes or if it’s more a higher-order issue (when well-rested, you eat better, etc.).

Sleep and appetite regulation

This paper shows that subjects limited to 4-6 hours of sleep per night for 1 week will have: 

Downregulated leptin (the satiety hormone that signals to your brain that you are full and don’t need to eat anymore) is turned down
Upregulated ghrelin (a hunger hormone signaling the body to eat more) is ramped up


People sleeping 6 hours a night will eat extra calories during the next day


Figure 1. Sleep loss and obesity. Image credit: Why We Sleep
Peter struggles with food choices when sleep deprived

When flying from NYC to California, he has to wake up at 4am
“That is unquestionably one of the worst eating days of my life if I let it be.”
Takes a ton of planning a brief moments of discipline to overcome the crazy cravings he has under those sleep deprived conditions (i.e. wants pizza for breakfast)
Tricks he’s learned

Will make sure to have a good filling breakfast before getting on the plane
Do not eat ANYTHING on the plane
When land in CA he will have a filling snack (avocado and macadamia nuts)
Won’t eat again until dinner which he will have early at 5pm
Then goes to bed at 8pm


Matthew: “So imagine someone like you [Peter] who has the knowledge that they have about sleep and then has this maniacal discipline to be able to fast for long periods of time. Even you with that arsenal of benefit in place can struggle under the weight of sleep deprivation. No wonder the majority of us non-demigods of control will implode so quickly.”

Jocko Willink 

Peter: “I’d love to see what Jocko would do under sleep deprived conditions with respect to food.”
Matthew: “I would love to have a conversation, just an honest frank conversation about sleep with him.”

Type of food

It’s not just that you overeat when you are underslept, it’s also the food profile that suffers

Study looking at food choices when sleep deprived: 

Subjects sleep 4-5 hours a night for a week
Let them eat anything they want from a buffet, they not only eat more calories but also worse foods (pizza, cookies, and ice cream instead of protein, nuts, and leafy greens) 

Brain scan study looking at reactions to food

Subjects with restricted sleep were shown pictures of different food while in a brain scanner
The prefrontal cortex of the brain, which keeps hedonic desires in check, is impaired by sleep deprivation
And the more primitive areas of the brain like the amygdala “erupted” in response to desirable foods

Decision making, workplace production, leadership qualities, physical attractiveness, and more [43:15] 
“Essentially, you’re losing impulse control networks within the brain.”
There are places where controlling impulsivity is critical yet sleep deprivation is common:

The military
Aviation
Stock markets (Michael Lewis has talked to Matthew about how common sleep deprivation is on Wall Street)

Work from Chris Barnes at University of Washington suggests that employees who are sleeping 6 hours or less:

First, these employees select less challenging problems
Second, they produce fewer creative solutions to the problems they do select
Third, employees working in teams just slack off and let others work (social loafing)
Four, they became more deviant and less ethical (they falsified data and reimbursement claims, they claimed they’d done work other people had actually done)

Study looking at leadership qualities and sleep deprivation

Looked at the sleep of a business leader
Found that less sleep he had, the less inspiring and charismatic his employees found him
“Even though they knew nothing about the sleep of that leader, it was evidential in their behavior.”

Sleep’s impact on physical appearance, dating, and mating
⇒ Sweden study of the perceived attractiveness of people in a rested state vs. a sleep deprived state

Took a picture of people under two conditions, full night sleep and sleep deprived
Then they asked neutral judges to rate their appearance
The unslept picture was consistently rated as less attractive, more sickly and tired looking
So there’s some scientific proof of “beauty sleep.”
If you are trying to find a mate or be intimate, you won’t look your best if you’re sleep deprived

The broken water pipe analogy [49:30]
“There is truly no aspect of a human being’s wellness that isn’t eroded by a lack of sleep. Lack of sleep is like a broken water pipe in your home. . .it will leak down into every nook and cranny of your physiology.”

Sleep impacts the macro (complex diseases, leadership qualities, and physical appearance)
Sleep impacts the micro (intracellular pathways, phosphorylation of AKT) 
Like leaking water, sometimes it’s gushing, and other times it’s a slow drip.
“There are few things in your biology or your psychology that can retreat at the sign of sleep deprivation and get away unscathed.”

Evolution didn’t prepare us for sleep deprivation

In an evolutionary sense, we’ve kept this strange thing around for half a billion years
Sleep is a ridiculous proposition and makes no sense on the surface
While you’re sleeping you can’t get food or mate or protect yourself or care for your children
We’ve had time to prepare for starvation (ketosis) and excess food as we evolved as a species

See this paper by Rick Johnson on genetic changes in metabolism of fructose allowed us to fatten up in the fall when fruit was sweeter, which was a little bit of preparation for what we do with excess nutrients in the modern era


But only in the last 150-250 years (and particularly the last 40) has there been a new pressure to reduce sleep

The negative effect of caffeine, alcohol, and high carb meals on sleep quality [53:30]
“We know for a fact that 10 million American adults in the past month have swallowed some kind of a sleep aid.”
Alcohol 

Alcohol is probably the most misunderstood “sleep aid”
But alcohol does 3 things to sleep: 

1) it’s a sedative so works like sleeping pills… you might lose consciousness more quickly, but you’re not “falling asleep” faster
2) alcohol fragments sleep so you wake up many more times during the night; often so brief that you don’t remember but they have an impact on your physiology
3) alcohol blocks REM sleep, so you wake up unrefreshed and unrestored



Caffeine

People often take caffeine (“adenosine-reducing substance”) to stay awake
Should not need caffeine before midday ⇒ your peak alertness should be around 11 or 12
Matthew notices that many people sleep on a plane at 10am when they should be getting to their most alert state

How caffeine works:

Adenosine builds up like a sleepiness signal and when you have a lot, it tells you to go to sleep
Caffeine blocks adenosine receptors in the brain ⇒ it’s hitting the “mute button” on sleepiness

How long does caffeine last in your system?

Caffeine has a half-life of 6 hours
And a quarter life of 12 hours
So if you drink a full cup of coffee at noon, quarter of that caffeine is still in the brain at midnight
It’s like drinking a quarter of a cup of coffee right before bed
Even for people who say they sleep just fine after consuming caffeine, one study showed that 200 mg of caffeine before bed resulted in a 20% reduction in deep sleep (the same as aging you 20 or 30 years to get the same drop)

Are there variations in people’s responses to caffeine?

Peter says caffeine has no effect on him, when he’s tired, it will NOT wake him up
Some people are more sensitive to it than others ⇒ There is variation in the genes that are associated with the enzyme that decomposes caffeine 
But… it is unclear whether people who are less sensitive to caffeine also have less reduction of their deep sleep.

Using the Oura ring to see the effects of alcohol

[Peter discloses that he is an investor and advisor in Oura] 
“There is no greater behavioral tool to show you the deleterious effects of alcohol than this ring.”
Most people’s sleep is affected with just one or two drinks
For Peter…

A single drink 4-5 hours before bed does not have an effect
But, 2 drinks 4-5 hours before bed, or just a single drink a couple hours before bed and “my sleep is shot”

Resting heart rate 6-8 beats higher
Heart rate variability is compressed by 20%
Respiratory rate is increased by 2 breaths/minute
Body temperature up by .3-.6 degrees






Figure 2. Oura ring results from Peter showing HRV
⇒ This is bad news for people who enjoy a night cap

You need your heart rate to decrease
You need to drop your core body temp by 2-3 degrees F to initiate sleep
But alcohol raises your core body temperature, so you get more fragmented sleep, more awakenings, and you disrupt REM sleep
“On every one of those levels, that’s exactly what we see in a scientific evidence.”

⇒ Alcohol makes you have to pee more in the night

Alcohol inhibits vasopressin
So you urinate disproportionately more than you’re consuming because it inhibits an anti-diuretic hormone

⇒ High carb meal before bed

A meal high in “bad” carbohydrates (i.e. bowl of cereal) can have a harmful effect on sleep quality similar to alcohol
Peter has seen this consistently in himself

The efficacy of THC and CBD as sleep aids [1:05:30]
Review of the literature on THC and CBD ⇒ Cannabis, Cannabinoids, and Sleep: a Review of the Literature. 
THC

THC is not a good sleep aid for a teenager (because their brain is still developing)

Does THC help sleep in adults?  ⇒ “No. I don’t think I’d feel comfortable in suggesting that it’s a pro sleep compound.”
What about different strains (sativa vs. indica)? ⇒ Not enough data to differentiate among strains
What does THC do for sleep?

THC does make you fall asleep faster (reduces sleep latency)
But like alcohol, it blocks REM sleep

THC tolerance

With regular use of THC…

you start to lose the sleep latency benefit
And if you try to quit using it, many people get “rebound insomnia” 



Cannabidiol (CBD)

There’s not enough data yet on CBD as a sleep aid, although the data is more promising than THC
But it’s very hard to get studies funded because of the “moral” factor
Matthew would love to do a study on CBD (is considering something like Kickstarter to crowdsource the funding)

What the early data on CBD is showing:

Falling asleep faster with CBD 
Early tentative preliminary evidence suggests it does not have the same negative impact on REM
Also fewer dependency issues and don’t get insomnia rebound
CBD might also benefit some sleep disorders

Might reduce severity of sleep apnea
Might also help PTSD-related sleep problems


Caveats

It’s dose dependent, and it’s not clear at this point what the optimal dose is
There may be other doses that are actually detrimental to sleep and we need to stay away from them
So it might that there is a U-curve with a “sweet spot” for dosing with other doses being detrimental to sleep



Does CBD increase your deep sleep?

Not enough evidence to say it definitely increases the amount of deep sleep
But there is some promising data (one single, small study)

By what mechanism is CBD potentially improving sleep?

Lowering core body temperature

One hypothesis is that CBD may decrease your core body temperature, leading to better sleep


Anxiety 

Another is indirect benefits through its reduction of anxiety, for which evidence is strongest right now
Anxiety is a major cause of insufficient or poor sleep
If you lower the “fight or flight” response, you get a more parasympathetic state and/or your core temperature drops



Peter has seen some anecdotal evidence of impressive results with CBD

Seems to especially work for people with existing sleep issues
For those who sleep well already, CBD doesn’t seem to improve it
And it does not work for everyone
But Peter has seen patients for which medications won’t work for them but CBD oil does, it’s not clear why

Sleep and mental health: A two-way street [1:16:45]
Case study of Peter’s patient:

Sleep quality was suffering even though they had tried everything…

Control the room temperature
Control the light
Control the nutrients and diet
Eliminate the alcohol
Eliminate the caffeine
Hour of meditation a day
50 milligrams of Thorazine to just try to shut off the ruminative properties


But the patient was facing a difficult personal struggle
He ended up using MDMA (under clinical supervision) to deal with some of the underlying issues (trauma, anxiety, depression, etc.)
The next day, and for several months now, he sleep has been fixed
Peter’s take:

“I think that is an outlier situation, but sometimes these outlier situations provide an insight into a mechanism.”
“To see this one thing, this one intervention work, and the patient would describe this as a transformational life experience, was just another example of the power of the mind and how the mind can get in its own way at times.”



The bi-directionality of sleep and mental health
“The rise in anxiety has walked in lockstep with a rise in insomnia. I think we’ve got enough evidence to suggest that those two are probably not coincidental, but are significantly interrelated.”

It goes both ways ⇒ Mental health affects sleep, but poor sleep also affects mental health
Deprive people of sleep…

People without psychological problems can develop depression, anxiety, poor mood, etc.  
One single night of sleep loss can induce clinical anxiety in a person who does not normally have it
“In the past 25 years, I have not been able to discover a single psychiatric condition in which sleep is normal.” says Matthew
“Sleep is essentially mental first aid.”


Give someone anxiety…

Their sleep suffers
Like Peter’s patient above, curing mental problems and you can correct sleep problems


Psychiatrists used to think poor sleep was a symptom of a disorder, but maybe they should have considered whether it was a cause

How long does it take to develop issues?

It may take some issues a long time to develop (dementia)
But others not long at all (memory consolidation and anxiety)
After about 16 hours of being awake many things start to go wrong, but mental health seems to be one of the quickest to fall apart

How sleep impacts memory, and Matthew’s current and upcoming projects [1:24:00]
What have you been doing during your sabbatical year?

Still the Director the Center for Human Sleep Science at Berkeley

Sleep’s impact on athletes: Looking at Formula One drivers [1:32:45]
Sleep really matters in Formula One car racing (or any high speed car racing, really)

F1 drivers are subject to incredible jet lag having to travel across the globe for races
Sleep deprivation is going to affect margin of error and reaction time, which are essential in racing
If there is one gold standard measure of insufficient sleep, it’s not only just your response time, your basic reaction time, but it’s the number of times that you miss a response
This is called a lapse, or an error of omission (You omitted a response that should have been happening)
Six hours of sleep for a week can drop your reaction time by as much as 300-400 milliseconds which in F1 racing can be the difference in being first and out of the race completely

Peter’s observations in his racing simulator

Even after one alcoholic drink, he drives worse in a simulator
Not legally drunk (.02-.03 BAC) even though I am not drunk and my blood alcohol is very low
And not just reaction time ⇒ His spatial coordination goes down, “which I think is a bigger problem” 

Things affected by insufficient sleep in drivers/athletes

Spatial attention: Matthew says something called “spatial attention” goes down very quickly under conditions of sleep deprivation
Quick decision making: When other racers are on the track, it becomes strategic and you have to make multiple decisions in split seconds, and sleep affects critical components of that
Judgement: It’s incredible how much your judgment can be impaired when others are on the track probably due to sleep’s impact on impatience and impulsivity (can lead to irrational thinking)
Physical fitness: 

It’s a physical sport too, and when your physical performance is mismatched to your natural circadian rhythm (like with jet lag) you will not be able to perform your best
Most world records are broken at the Olympics during the peak of most circadian rhythm (about 1 or 2 in the afternoon)


As an F1 driver, if you’re shifting dramatically among time zones, you are losing a competitive advantage
We may be at maximum saturation with engineering and technology; it’s humans themselves that are important.  Athletes are paying attention to diet, nutrition, and mental health, but sleep is a factor too.

“A team could spend 10 million on trying to shave off .1 of a second in a car, which would be heroic as an engineering accomplishment, yet you could be shaving off point .4 or .5 by way of human error by way of this thing called insufficient sleep, or mismatched circadian rhythm.”
What separates the top professional athletes?

Peter says it’s the ability to be consistently exceptional
Peter, for example, can have one exceptional lap in a racecar
But the pros must do 70+ in a row for more than 2 hours without making a single error
That is a ton of focus and concentration for a long period of time (more so than most other sports) ⇒ in neuroscience they refer to this as the “time on task effect”

Time on task effect

The longer you do something, your sustained attention will wane for pretty much any cognitive task
The longer you apply yourself to a task, the more insufficient sleep shows
For example, for the first 30 seconds they perform as if they are rested, but at about 4-5 minutes in you really see a difference in performance if they are sleep deprived
The biggest effect of sleep deprivation in terms of time on task is in sustained attention and sustained spatial attention so paying attention to these effects would be a benefit to racers
